Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

A third of you (still) want Pluto to be a planet.  But it’s not. So get over it.

1321335378217963521.text:
Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

Nearly (only?) 400 out of 185,000 respondents have been hospitalized for COVID-19. Of course we don’t know how many have died. But for all others, please continue to stay smart, stay healthy, and heed the advice medial professionals

1321335377408466944.text:
Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

7% of you are Vegan/Vegetarian, which is close to the 8% of you in the world’s population.  Meanwhile, nearly 90% are omnivores, I among you. Although lately I consume dead animals no more than about two days a week.

1321335376590635008.text:
Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

More than 80% of you are non-religious. But one in 14 (7%) identify as having religion as a way of life. You follow me knowing that not all of my content resonates with your views. Thank you for coming along for the ride.

1321335375781134343.text:
Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

One fourth of you identify as politically Centrist with more than half identifying as Liberal.  So the Conservative voices that arise in my threads, though ardent, are a small minority of all followers.

1321335374942261248.text:
Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

One in four of you have visited only one, or no other countries in your life. In my experience, it’s always good to do all you can to see how others live — lest you think your way of life is the only way of life.

1321335374132748289.text:

1321333782092353536.text:
Reflections on the statistics of my followers:

Most of you are half my age or less. More significantly, only 3.5% of my followers are my age or older. That’s half of who in that age group uses Twitter.

I wish I knew what any of that means.

1321333781224132609.text:
Thanks for participating in my two-day, 14-question Twitter Poll.  Nearly everyone who answered did so within 12 hours.   Thanks for this enthusiasm.

What follows is a thread of my Reflections on the statistics of who you are.

1320765801738231809.text: @GinaGenebone697 Excellent question.  I need to cross-correlate a lot of these answers, and especially compare with base averages from Twitter itself, before we can draw any reliable conclusions about my followers.

1320757113031938049.text: (11/14) What best describes how Religious you are?

1320757110666309637.text: (9/14) How many other Countries have you ever visited?

1320757109420707844.text: (8/14) How many spoken Languages do you understand?

1320757108174921729.text: (7/14) What is (or will be) your final Education Level?

1320757105796747267.text: (5/14) How would you identify your Skin Color?

1320757104546881536.text: (4/14) Are you fluent with the Metric System?

1320757103292747776.text: (3/14) What part of your Country do you live in?

1320757102013460480.text: (2/14) Which Earth Hemisphere do you live in?

1320757100604231680.text: (1/14) How old are you in Earth-years?

1244297149678006275.text: If you must know:  The word parsec is a contraction of “parallax-second”, the distance a star would be from the Sun if one half of its parallax angle subtended one second of arc.

1244294662480936962.text: Ignoring the Kessel Run abomination in Star Wars, a Parsec is an obscure unit of distance in classical astronomy equal to 3.26 light years. A megaparsec is a million of these. So for every megaparsec, the universe is expanding an additional 70 km/sec — the famous Hubble Constant. https://t.co/OKyzlNCESY

Credit to Pope Gregory’s Jesuit priests for figuring out the Julian calendar needed updating - before telescopes, and while Christendom was sure the Sun orbited Earth.

1233813145883496449.text: By 1582, the Julian calendar, with a Leap Day every four years, had accumulated TEN extra days relative to Earth’s orbit.  So Pope Gregory jump-started his new and exquisitely accurate calendar by canceling 10 days that year, in which October 4 was followed by October 15.

1233811244026605570.text:
The 1582 Gregorian update to the Julian Calendar prescribes: The century years 1600 1700 1800 1900 & 2000 are all divisible by four, but 1700 1800 1900 were not leap years, yet 1600 & 2000 were. And 2400 will be.

On February 29, 2000 most had no idea how rare that Leap Day was.

1233808998647898113.text:
The Leap Day alone overcorrects the calendar, requiring we remove a Leap Day every century year.

But that under-corrects the calendar, requiring we put a Leap Day back in, every four centuries. 

Behold the Gregorian Calendar.

1199080829064024065.text: @elonmusk Electric vehicles are famously heavy - over both axles. It’s all about the weight borne by spinning tires. That’s the source of traction, not the engine power.

1199074711478644741.text: @elonmusk A badass @Tesla looking like it’s doing a badass thing.  But if the @Ford F-150 is RWD **with no payload** then weight on the Rear Axle is greatly reduced, offering only mild traction for the Tesla to overcome. This contest is more about the Physics of Friction than Engine Power.

1106179058335911936.text:
Not that anybody asked, but…
 
Measure the circumference of your head in inches, then divide that number by Pi. That’s your Hat size.

Mathematically, your Hat size is the diameter of your head in inches if your head were a perfect sphere.

1106176924525776896.text:
So that we're all on the same Pi-page…

If you measure the Circumference of a circle and divide it by the Diameter of the same circle, you get the value of Pi.  And that value of Pi is the same for ANY size circle you draw.

1048252978493358080.text: #IKnewIWasOld the day I figured out that back when I was 30 years old, I didn’t know shit about anything.

1048251720797700097.text: #IKnewIWasOld when all I wanted to do after a good meal is take a nap.

1048250461860458498.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I started caring about the “I’ve Fallen and I Can’t Get Up!” TV commercials.

1048249204349517824.text: #IKnewIWasOld when the Obituary Pages became a fascinating read.

1048247945810907136.text: #IKnewIWasOld when Adult fans come up to me and say “I watched you on PBS when I was a kid.”

1048246687398088704.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I decided to to drink bottles of Wine that cost twice as much, but do so only half as often.

1048245429639553024.text: #IKnewIWasOld when it became unsafe to ignite the appropriate number of Candles on my Birthday Cake.

1048244170790502400.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I stopped liking Barbecue Potato Chips

1048242912461344770.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I started liking all the Music my parents listened to.

1048241654577209344.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I saw the next generation complain about social issues that my generation didn’t yet have the awareness to notice.

1048240395673432065.text: #IKnewIWasOld when the urge to go exercise was easily overrun by the competing urge to take a nap.

1048239137596293120.text: #IKnewIWasOld when at Restaurants, I started ordering appetizers for my main course.

1048237882295693312.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I could no longer do a full split on a dance floor, but also no longer cared that I couldn’t.

1048236621219450880.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I started caring more about what is objectively true than about hurting people’s feelings.

1048235363234435073.text: #IKnewIWasOld when my family started buying number-candles to represent my age on a Cake rather than single candles themselves.

1048234104737619969.text: #IKnewIWasOld the day my growing son was simultaneously bigger than I wanted to lift, and bigger than I was able lift.

1048232845842382848.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I could swallow a shot of Whisky without wincing.

1048231587777634305.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I would walk past a Candy Store and not even notice I was walking past a Candy Store.

1048230329436139520.text: #IKnewIWasOld when the threat of being sent to bed early sounded like a reward rather than a punishment.

1048220012081762305.text: #IKnewIWasOld when I had no interest in accelerating faster than the guy next to me out of the traffic light that just turned green.

1048211455705722880.text: #IKnewIWasOld when on my 60th birthday, I didn’t feel a day over 60.

A GOLFER QUERIES A BASEBALL PLAYER:

Where’s the ball when you swing?

Whizzing by at 90 mph - the pitcher does not want me to hit it.

How quiet Is the crowd?

They’re making as much noise as possible.

How much time do you have to swing?

Four tenths of a second.

1006267802825711616.text:
A BASEBALL PLAYER QUERIES A GOLFER:

How fast is the ball moving when you swing?

It’s stationary - at my feet.

Does the crowd cheer?

No, they’re silent — even the announcers whisper.

After you hit the ball, where do you run?

We don’t run at all — often, we don’t even walk.

980488852606304257.text: @cnimbelli I’m a fan of vowels wherever they lurk: “F", when pronounced alone, is spelled “ef”, which begins with a vowel. Hence the “an” preceding my “FYI" abbreviation. Had FYI been spelled out, the “F" sound changes, becoming the first letter of “For”, then deserving a preceding “a”.

980464870452740096.text: Just an FYI: Easter on the Gregorian Calendar contains a double astronomical reference: The first Sunday after the first Full Moon after the Vernal (Spring) Equinox. Eclipses, which occur only during new or full moons, can therefore never happen on Easter Sunday.

651207268747218944.text: #WhenIWasYourAge it was people who were smart, and phones that were dumb.

651206008954458112.text: #WhenIWasYourAge James Bond was probably infected with multiple STDs.

651204741599395840.text: #WhenMyParentsWereYourAge “In God We Trust" was neither on our money, the Pledge of Allegiance, or the front wall of Congress

651203495924645889.text: #WhenIWasYourAge The weather started feeling cold in September.

651202220931706881.text: #WhenIWasYourAge My car got seven miles per gallon. Ten, downhill. Twelve, with a tailwind.

651200964142039040.text: #WhenIWasYourAge, Before scooper laws, nobody knew for sure what squeezing Dog Poop into the palm of your hand felt like.

651199728151982084.text: #WhenIWasYourAge You could kiss your loved-one goodbye at the airport gate. And return home.

651198463414177796.text: #WhenIWasYourAge People dressed up when they flew on Airplanes.

651197208075702277.text: #WhenIWasYourAge A commercial airplane, the Concorde, cruised at twice the speed of sound — 3x faster than planes today.

651195939328147456.text: #WhenIWasYourAge America had the tallest buildings in the world.

651194675726974976.text: #WhenIWasYourAge America launched its own Astronauts into space — with its own Spaceships.

651193413207887872.text: #WhenIWasYourAge We cured diseases and went to the Moon, benchmarking our usage of the word “Awesome."

651192151892606976.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Rain Forests were called Jungles. And Wetlands were called Swamps.

651189638745296900.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Partly sunny days were called partly cloudy.

651188386581970944.text: #WhenIWasYourAge All hotel rooms smelled of cigarette smoke.

651187884641284096.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Second-hand smoke was when somebody offered you a toke on whatever they were puffing.

651187125560283139.text: #WhenIWasYourAge An ashtray was a time-honored gift you could bring to a person's home.

651185865260072960.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Extracting ketchup from its narrow-necked glass bottle occasionally made you question the laws of gravity.

651184616900980736.text: #WhenIWasYourAge We had candy cigarettes, gun-shaped cigarette lighters, and sucked flavored sugar through a straw.

651183351219380225.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Corn Pops Frosted Flakes & Honey Smacks were instead called Sugar Pops Sugar Frosted Flakes & Sugar Smacks

651182091338539009.text: #WhenIWasYourAge We consumed Twinkles, Cool Whip, and Yoo-hoo, without questioning their chemical composition.

651180844099342337.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Milk was not yet the farthest thing from the front entrance to your grocery store.

651179590551867392.text: #WhenIWasYourAge A photograph lived inside your camera, cloaked in mystery for weeks, until you took exactly 35 more photos.

651178334634684417.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Photographs were records of your life experience, and not the life experience itself.

651177069116682240.text: #WhenIWasYourAge Pluto was a planet. T-Rex dragged his tail. And the Brontosaurus was always chewing vegetation.

538452326852198400.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Religion was taught in Sunday School, not in your Science Classroom.

538451072876961792.text: Thanks for your time.  I think I’ve got only one more left in me...

538450050959958016.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: The Soviet KGB would’ve killed for the surveillance & checkpoint measures that are common in the USA today

538449268072136704.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Looking up somebody's number in the Phone Book was only one of a dozen household uses for it.

538448547297759232.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: You needed a can opener to open a can of beer. And you’d put two holes in it. The second, for air flow.

538447803299557376.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: There was hardly any transparent plastic.

538447001734500352.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: There were ten known asteroids with orbits crossing Earth's. Now, we know more than ten-thousand.

538446254410199040.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We actually used a sheet of paper laced with carbon to make a carbon copy — “the cc:" -- of a Letter.

538445529202434048.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: PaulSimon wrote this pre-GlobalWarming lyric "The autumn winds blow chilly & cold, September I'll remember”

538445529198243840.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Exhaust from City buses billowed at the perfect height for everybody nearby to inhale it.

538444777205690368.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: People were never "living with their disease". We cured them. Or they died from it.

538443989603454976.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Airplanes were so loud, you had to pause your conversation whenever one flew overhead.

538443219407618048.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: No matter what they contained, Bottles were not squeezable.

538442494690615297.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Your home telephone could drop to the floor thousands of times and never break.

538441721751678977.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We made phone calls in Phone Booths, which is also where Superman occasionally changed his clothes.

538440962691702785.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: On average, the Moon was about 1.5 meters closer to Earth than it is today.

538440219519770624.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Earth's daily rotation was about a half a millisecond faster than today.

538439488213495808.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Before Xerox copiers, we all got high in elementary school by smelling mimeograph ink.

538438705069834240.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: The average Watermelon had a Billion seeds in it.

538437263042961408.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: When you fell off the monkey-bars in the playground you landed on cement.

538436429785751552.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We used large Maps made of paper, and none of us could ever re-fold them back the way they came.

538435928113414144.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: My car got seven miles per gallon. With a tail-wind.

538435167438659585.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: You knew where & when the constellations could be found in the sky by using your “Brain App”.

538434448207785984.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: The meat in a fast-food Hamburger was as large as the Bun itself.

538433684169179137.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We went to the Moon -- nine times. Today, in low Earth-Orbit, we boldly go where hundreds have gone before.

538432959028539392.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Your expected age of death was much closer to your age of retirement.

538432672084013056.text: Want more?  Or am I clogging your inbox?

538431420020957187.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: There were hardly any one-way streets.

538430634520092672.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: You had to actually get off your butt, and approach the TV to change the channel.

538429940153069568.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Being "all thumbs" meant you were clumsy.  Today it means you’re good at texting.

538428885004599297.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: We had to open all doors by ourselves. None of them knew we were coming.

538427397691826177.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: It took a week to learn whether your photos came out okay.

538426623117107200.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: It took a whole hour to bake a potato.

538425908554526720.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Pluto was a planet, but those "in the know" all knew its days were numbered.

538425132671176704.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Weather predictions were no more than guesses about whether it might rain tomorrow.

538424379672395776.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: Anything wrapped in plastic was easy to open.

538424329152000000.text: #WhenIWasYourAge: None of my toothpaste tubes could stand up on their caps.

513115400528068608.text: So “Alpha" Centauri is the brightest star in the constellation Centaurus. And “Beta" Pictoris is the 2nd brightest in Pictor.

513114126210437121.text: Apart from common names, stars are generally ID'ed in order of brightness within a constellation, using the Greek alphabet.

513112829260357632.text: The Southern skies have the closest star system to the Sun - the famed “Alpha Centauri”  The 3rd brightest in the night sky.

513111593006014465.text: Earth is closest to the Sun during the Southern Hemisphere Summer. For the North, that of course coincides with our winter.

513110352037298178.text: Many big telescope in the North have twins in the South, giving astrophysicists coherent full-sky coverage of the Universe.

513109063895220224.text: Just an FYI: Earth’s South Magnetic Pole is actually in the North. That’s why the North tip of a compass needle points there.

513105804262506496.text: The center of the Milky Way — a target of study for my PhD — passes directly overhead for all middle southern latitudes.

513104525356318720.text: “Arctic" derives from Arktos, the Greek word for Bear. The Arctic's got em. (For now.) The Ant-Arctic doesn't.

513103269942411264.text: What’s the North Pole? Curl the fingers of your right hand in the direction of rotation. Stick out your thumb. That’s North.

1339403081323323392.text:
Confusing planetary motion terminology time:

A planet ROTATES (spins around on its axis) while it REVOLVES (orbits in space) around the Sun.

One trick to remember the difference: think of spinning plates and cars going around tracks. "Rotate like a plate, revolve like a Volvo."

1337827753786298370.text: @alb202 @tarahaelle Well all vaccines are set up to goad your body into mounting an immune defense, one way or another, and sometimes that'll make you feel a bit gross for a bit. In this case, after your cells make the proteins, they immediately recognize that they're foreign and attack them.

1337826807345803268.text: Having a good, varied, balanced diet is unquestionably a good idea but it's really no substitute for giving your immune system a chance to develop virus-killing antibodies precisely tailored to the specific virus you're worried about before it catches you by surprise.

1337825710984060929.text: Often when I hear hesitancy about vaccines it's framed in terms of "we should just strengthen our immune systems" (suggesting vitamins or whatever) but it's hard to imagine a better way to help out your immune system than by showing it what the threat is so it can prepare. https://t.co/qIz5ip8mic

1337806747738763266.text: (If you have questions about the COVID-19 vaccines, check out this very comprehensive piece by @tarahaelle https://t.co/uZXxRHlJCS)

1337805677771755520.text: It's kind of like instead of capturing the invading army's soldiers and weapons, you've got the 3D-printer files for their tanks and bombs and guns, and so now you can make them yourself, find every little weakness, and destroy them on sight if they actually arrive.

1337805673946603524.text: mRNA vaccines, like Moderna & Pfizer/BioNTech's, work differently. They give your cells the blueprints for a piece of the virus, so your cells can build that piece (which, on its own, can't hurt you), study it, & be ready to attack it & the virus it's attached to when it shows up

1337805672306663425.text: Usually, a vaccine gives your immune system dead or weakened pathogens so it can mount a specialized defense. Say an invading army is coming and you capture some soldiers and their weapons. You'll be in a much better position to repel the invasion than if caught by surprise!

1337805671119646726.text: Vaccines are combat training for your immune system. They show it what to expect from a virus/bacteria so your cells can build a better defense when the actual pathogen arrives.

1337793437379293184.text: @Correctioneer @pzmyers This doesn't need to be a thread. I see I misread your tweet. Neither the aggregator nor the research institution is paid for the running of the ad. The research institution is producing the PR as an ad for the institution.

1337792598900092928.text: @Correctioneer @pzmyers No, the news aggregators don't pay to run the content. That doesn't mean the content isn't an ad.

1337791744453324803.text: @Correctioneer @pzmyers The press release itself is essentially an ad for the research institution.

1337791132173033472.text: @CyberSpaceGal That's actually one of the more responsible ones, in that it includes the press release's author's name (though I didn't see a link back to the press release itself). Many tweak a little and don't include the author of the PR at all, or credit the institution.

1337784140578643971.text:
@CyberSpaceGal Here’s an example: https://t.co/eIpWv9dd3M

Original press release: https://t.co/iR1V4SUElf

1337781597823700993.text: As a reader, you can usually spot these kinds of articles by the fact that no external comment is sought or given and the discovery or publication is presented with only favorable context. Outlets like PhysOrg print these all the time, but dressed up to read like journalism.

1337781076954148866.text: Scicomm hot take: Press releases (from universities, research institutions, etc) are *sponsored content* and should be clearly labeled as such when reprinted by science news aggregators.

When I'm asked to give advice to students, the #1 piece of advice I give is this:

Just because a subject is hard for you (math/science/etc), that doesn't mean you're "not cut out for it." You don't have to be a natural at your chosen subject. It's okay if you have to work hard.

1334177728032075776.text: @WakeRevolt Basically the issue is that the farther away something is, the more in the past we see it. We can't see the distant past of nearby stuff and we can't see the present of far away stuff. And because the CMB is really just a view of space in the distant past, we only see it far away

1334177187050688512.text: 🗣 Free online talk tonight about #BLACKHOLES and what this year's Physics Nobel Prize was all about! Hosted by @naturalsciences and given by @ncstatephysics grad student @SamDFlynn. 7pm Eastern, link here: https://t.co/gH2dbyqSJv https://t.co/rcfOpsLuKZ

1334175202478055424.text: @WakeRevolt So we only see that radiation (the CMB) from points that are so far away from us that the light took 13.8 billion years to cross that distance. The (primordial) radiation from anything nearer passed us long ago.

1334174909652725761.text: @WakeRevolt ...Basically what's happening is that every point WAS "on fire" 13.8 billion years ago, and when the plasma cooled and the radiation dissipated it travelled out in every direction from every point. The radiation from the plasma that existed at a point close to us is FAR away now.

1334174548904828929.text: @WakeRevolt This is a good question! The answer is that there are CMB photons throughout the Universe, but all of them are arriving at whatever point they're at FROM points that are about 46 billion light years away. In my book, Figures 2 and 3 might help with this...

1324483296995192834.text: (If you want to read more and better things about Many Worlds, check out @seanmcarroll's book, Something Deeply Hidden: https://t.co/qq8rGluOFe or @FreelanceAstro's about the development of interpretations of quantum mechanics, What is Real?: https://t.co/M4EXZc7LNh)

1324481676756570112.text: So next time you are waiting for the result of some process or experiment, if the Many Worlds interpretation is correct, perhaps you're not, in fact, learning about something happening in the world, really. Perhaps what you're learning is what world you actually live in.

1324481675812868101.text: In the Many Worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics, the wavefunction never collapses. All possibilities happen, they just happen in different universes. If you measure "electron went left" you're not measuring the electron, you're ACTUALLY measuring which universe YOU'RE in.

1324481674932064258.text: That question is what different interpretations of quantum mechanics try to answer. How do we go from probabilities to single answers? You start with a "wavefunction" that contains all possibilities and end with a data point: you could say the wavefunction collapsed to one result

1324481674051309570.text: When you measure the electron's position, you'll find it either went left or right, and depending on how you set up the experiment, it might be that half the time you do it, you'll find left-electron, half the time right-electron. How does each electron "decide" which way to go?

1324481673254359047.text: In quantum mechanics, there's uncertainty built into every physical process. Let's say an electron could go left or right at a junction. Before you check, you can't know where the electron is: you say the result is a superposition of electron-going-left and electron-going right.

1331318232406499331.text: @RealDC80 Yes but this isn’t about people. It’s about your food. It comes through that border. Not to mention car parts, medicines, livestock (both ways), etc. The point is that these are our geographic neighbours, and we will always trade predominantly with them.

1297551867933859842.text: And my last comment on this thread. I have no idea which if any of the above frameworks is the correct way to think about it - perhaps all of them! I just find it interesting to try out different frameworks in an attempt to understand the world!

1297550878954708995.text: This isn’t necessarily to allege bad faith by the way - all politicians want to be in power. It’s just to say that any Brexit deal outcome is possible if you think in this way because it’s not so important to them.

1297462649668677632.text: @andrewhdonohoe @tudor_lancs @ShippersUnbound @Sime0nStylites Yes. I'm not arguing about the merits of Brexit at all. I'm discussing frameworks within which government actions might be analysed.

1297457639081861120.text: @ComeOanTheWell That is an analysis within the framework of the Rational Actor Model. Which may be correct, but it's necessary to understand that isn't the only model one could use. That's my point, basically.

1297454675827068929.text: 6. I think if the Government Politics Model is the best framework to understand this government, then I may disagree with myself and a no deal Brexit may indeed be the outcome.

1297454417902538753.text: 5. Another is the "Government Politics Model", which I think may apply here. The outcome is best understood like a sort of Medieval court, with different actors jostling for power and producing a sub-optimal outcome.

1297453905748594690.text: 4. There are other ways of analysing how particular outcomes happen. One is the "Organisational Process Model" - essentially governments are complex organisations and competing bureaucracies and structures within government lead to the outcome.

1297453026861604865.text: 3. The assumption in the Rational Actor Model is that Governments act like individuals. They have a goal in mind and they behave in a way that they think will optimise their chances of achieving this goal. In this case a no-deal Brexit.

1297452652545085446.text: 2. There is another potential 'fallacy' or assumption one could identify in this reasoning, identified in a famous book on the Cuban Missile Crisis - "Essence of Decision". It's called the "Rational Actor Model".

1266277737221611520.text: Also note the range of values of R (they label it the 90% credible interval). This represents the accuracy with which R is known given the available data and modelling. You can take it to mean R could actually be anywhere within the quoted range.

1266273867678404617.text: @Hollysmum It’s just the number of days it takes for the number of cases to halve (minus sign) or double (plus sign). If R is greater than 1 then cases will double over some number of days. If it’s less than 1 they will halve over some number of days.

1266273475200614401.text: @SamiMcNally If there is a minus sign in front of the number in the last column, it tells you how many days it will take for the number of cases to halve. If there is a plus sign, it tells you how many days it will take for number of cases to double.

1266271272700264454.text: @cricket_foot Halving times have a minus sign. You can see that R below 1 always corresponds to some halving time.

1266270129765011456.text: This is a very useful table because you can see clearly the effect of the R number on doubling / halving time. Rounding errors clearly visible, which shows you how sensitive exponentials are! This is why increases / decreases of 0.1 in R matter when it’s close to 1. https://t.co/PgiAH1xXGZ

1256250610313240581.text: @jlz0z I've done my best. I direct you to an introductory textbook for further reading. My favourite, and reasonably priced on Kindle, is Hartle, "Gravity".

1256237335009800194.text: @jlz0z In FRW cosmology one can define a family of slices of simultaneity (3D spacelike hypersurfaces) such that the temperature of the CMB would be measured to be the same at all points on the surface. That’s a definition of ‘now’.

1256217770456494082.text: @jlz0z You are confusing two things. Yes, there is no unique definition of ‘now’ in relativity. BUT in cosmology you can define a time; for example the average density of the Universe when the photon was emitted defines a time. Or, proper time along worldline of freely falling clock.
